results.title: London 1942
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Peter Tanner, Ralph Keene, Greenpark Productions and Verity Films
results.brief_description: A Picture of Wartime London: “A picture of London in 1942 showing a cheerful though bomb-scarred city. The streets are full of British and Allied servicemen. In the parks there are allotments; tomatoes grow on roof tops. The film shows Londoners in the Home Guard and Civil Defence. It ends with scenes of London after dark.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1942-1943)

results.title: Island people
results.creator_credit: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)
results.brief_description:
How Six People Spend Saturday: “It is Saturday in Britain, the day divided between work and rest. In the morning six people, representative of various types, are seen at work in the industrial areas, on the farms and in the cities. They are a craftsman from the Midlands, a typist in a big Manchester office, a tug captain on the River Thames, a farmer from the Lowlands of Scotland, a woman doctor from Cardiff and a small boy who lives in a suburb.
At midday the people crowd out of offices, factories and schools, all going home to prepare for the half-holiday.
Saturday afternoon is set aside for enjoyment. Out they go to their games and amusements, to play football and hockey, rugby and running, to work in the garden, to walk in the woods. At the end of the afternoon they go out to various places of amusement, or they return home to read and play or to make clothes or model aeroplanes.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1940)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)

results.title: The Race
results.creator_credit: Nikki Rose, First Light and Kinetoscope Productions
results.brief_description: Neil and David met at nursery school. There was something different about Neil but David liked him, even though he often got himself into a bad temper. Neil knew that because of his condition eventually they would part company but David vowed that they would always remain best friends.

results.title: One Man's Walk
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Mitchell, First Light and Interplay Theatre
results.brief_description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.

results.title: A Mile in our Shoes
results.creator_credit: Daniel Walker, Sarah Mortimer, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, First Light, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and The Junction
results.brief_description: The average age of a young carer in the UK is 12. This is a poignant and moving tribute to those many young carers tending to parents or siblings or both. They manage the domestic needs of a household as well as the physical needs of those they are caring for. They sometimes care for more than one family member with ailments ranging from autism to muscular dystrophy. With a constant lack of understanding from the rest of the world, no wonder there is little time for sleep let alone a social life.

results.title: Destination Point
results.creator_credit: Argyle Primary School, Bloom Productions and First Light
results.brief_description: Year 5 Primary school pupils from Kings Cross explore the ethnic diversity of their area and school. Kings Cross is an international destination point. Thousands of people travel in and out of the station every day. Some are travelling through on their way to somewhere else, some come into work and others travel to Kings Cross and make it home.

results.title: Until My Heart's, Like, Finished
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Martin Hodgson, Phil Shepherd, First Light and Somerset Film
results.brief_description: On the day of your 16th birthday, your mum kicks you out of home for good. You live in a car. You sofa surf. You sleep rough. Life for these young people has been tough with many challenges. Here they tell their stories in their own words, reveal they have learnt about how to survive and make plans for putting their lives back together.

results.title: Prehistoric Pet Shop
results.creator_credit: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light
results.brief_description: Prehistoric Pet Shop is about a caveman whose alarm clock stops working. But not just any alarm clock - the clock was a bird with an unfortunate heart problem. The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. A homage to Monty Python’s parrot sketch, this hilarious short reveals that complaining can get you more than just a new alarm clock.

results.title: Olympic Legacy: this was forever
results.creator_credit: Mark Aitken, First Light and Polkadotsonraindrops
results.brief_description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.
results.description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. results.title: My Grandma
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Taylor, First Light, Smith and Watson Productions and Wide Eyed
results.brief_description: Jamie is a girl who just wants to enjoy herself. However, she is constantly called upon to care for her demanding Grandmother. She is tired of hearing tales of Grandma’s childhood whilst missing out on her own. Successfully demonstrating the difference between two generations of women, will her Grandma’s constant nagging and complaining push Jamie too far?
